Titusville and Noxon Library Media Specialist Suzanne McRae worked with students and other librarians to support The Students Rebuild Hunger challenge, which she learned about from Arthur S. May's Janice Rifenburg. Each year, the Bezos Family Foundation invites students to respond to a specific problem affecting young people somewhere in the world. This year the focus was on world hunger. The Foundation is identifying additional opportunities to support hunger due to the COVID-19 pandemic.

How it works...students were asked to create an art based recipe. For every recipe that our students submitted, the Bezos Foundation makes a $6 donation to a respected community-based organization serving youth. Mrs. McRae set up a team site for Titusville/Noxon on the Rebuild Hunger website. https://bit.ly/36ixhhy #Arlingtonspirit

On Saturday, May 16, at 8pm, the Council of Chief State School Officers (CCSSO) is partnering with XQ Institute on Graduate Together: America Honors the High School Class of 2020, a one-hour primetime show paying joyful tribute to high school seniors, their extraordinary teachers, and their families. This commercial-free special will air on ABC, CBS, FOX, and NBC, and it will also be available on Facebook, Instagram, PEOPLE, Snapchat, TikTok, and YouTube.

During the show, high school seniors and other viewers will be invited to visit the Graduate Together website and click on their state to see specialized content for their graduating class. Students may visit the national Graduate Together website to submit photos, videos, and speeches for a chance to be featured on the show. We encourage you to tune in on Saturday to help celebrate the remarkable and resilient Class of 2020! Click here for details: https://www.graduatetogether2020.com/

Mission Arlington is a series of videos featuring Arlington students, staff, or alumni who are living the Arlington mission. Their messages are meant to inspire and to add an extra smile to your day.

Evelynn is a third grader at Noxon Road Elementary School. She spends much of her time riding and taking care of a pony named Norman. When not with Norman, her favorite activity is playing outside. Her favorite subjects in school are lunch, recess, writing, and math. She likes to write fairytales. She loves to read and says, “Barnes and Noble is like heaven to me.” Her favorite book series is Geronimo Stilton.

Evelynn, like several of the students recently featured in our Mission Arlington series, is an ardent environmental advocate. In her video, she shares some simple steps for protecting marine life and reducing the impact of plastic straws. According to National Geographic 500 million plastic straws are used in the U.S. every single day.

Vinny is a third grader at Joseph D’Aquanni West Road Intermediate School. He wrote a book called “Every Grade Feeling Book” which he shared with all of his classmates at West Road. His advice includes reading a book, counting to 50, or playing with a fidget if you are angry or anxious. If you are sad, think about something happy or wiggle. If you are tired, drink some water and get up and walk around. If you are sick, go to the nurse, but “if they find out you are faking, you get put back into school.” Watch Vinny’s video for some great advice.

When he is not writing books, he enjoys reading them. His favorite author is Mo Willems. Vinny also likes playing video games, running around, and having water balloon fights with his family.

Mission Arlington is a series of videos featuring Arlington students who are living the Arlington mission. Their messages are meant to inspire and to add an extra smile to your day.

Interviewing Shyanne, a senior at Arlington High School, was an early holiday gift. Her maturity, positivity, and spirit is truly inspiring. Make sure to share her uplifting video with your children!

Shyanne is president of the Spanish club and a member of Link Crew (a club that helps orientate and welcome 9th graders to AHS). She recently joined the anthropology club to broaden her horizons, asserting the importance of trying new things.

Shyanne’s favorite classes are English and math. She is an avid reader. Her favorite book is “The Clown” by Heinrich Boll. After graduation, Shyanne plans to attend Dutchess Community College to fulfill her general education requirements. She is considering careers in business or communications, but she is “ still exploring and figuring it out.”

Enjoy Shyanne’s motivating message! Wishing the Arlington community a joyous holiday season and a happy New Year!

Colin is a fifth grader at Beekman Elementary School. He strives to always be kind because “helping others impacts the community. I want the community to be a better place. If everyone is kind and nice, it will make the world a better place.”

Colin loves sports, especially baseball and basketball. He enjoys spending quality time with his family. His favorite school subjects are social studies and science. He especially likes chemistry because “combining so many things equals one big thing.” He notes that borax solution plus white glue makes slime!

Colin has Type I diabetes. To deal with diabetes he tries to “treat my body well and stay active.” Hear his message about the importance of perseverance.

On Wednesday, May 22, Arlington High School will host "Prevention Starts with All: The Chris Herren Story" from 7:00pm to 8:00pm in the high school auditorium. This event is free and open to the public. We encourage Arlington students and parents to attend together. Visit the News section at www.arlingtonschools.org for a printable flyer!

Chris Herren, a basketball legend from Fall River,Massachusetts, was an All-American, broke scoring records and was recruited by the nation’s top colleges. Herren realized his lifelong dream of playing in the NBA when he was drafted by the Denver Nuggets in 1999 and then traded to his hometown team, the Boston Celtics, before losing his career and almost his family to the disease of addiction.

In long-term recovery since 2008, Chris inspires people to start the conversation on wellness and educate themselves on the disease of addiction. It is his hope that strength will be found in the struggle and communities will come TOGETHER to address the issue of substance use disorder, advocate for effective treatment and embrace the power of recovery.

Championship Twirlers Encourage Kindness and Respect

Last April, Micah, a 6th grader at UVMS won the gold medal the for the USA with her duet partner in their division in Lillehammer, Norway! This past July she qualified again to represent the US in Limoges, France this August! Micah is the youngest member on Team USA and will be competing in the 2-baton event! Micah’s sister, Hannah, is a third grader at VFES and is the NYS Champion baton twirler in her division!

At the last home AHS boys’ varsity basketball game, the girls, along with two of their teammates, performed a baton twirling routine to the song “Shake It Off” to encourage our students to shake off the behaviors of those who treat others with disrespect. They will continue to perform it for Arlington students to encourage them to be strong role models by being kind to others and treating everyone with respect.#bekind

In 2017, Arlington High School featured Rebound: The Chris Herren Story. Chris Herren was a high school basketball legend who scored over 2,000 career points and was named to the 1994 McDonald's All-American team. Herren realized his lifelong dream of playing in the NBA only to lose it all to the nightmare of drug addiction—first alcohol, then cocaine and OxyContin, and finally heroin. Alcohol and drug-free since August 1, 2008, he has refocused his life to put his sobriety and family above all else.

Now, two high school seniors would like to bring Chris back to speak to our community. Thinking about how substance abuse has impacted their families, Julianna and Sierra are hosting a 3K Walk/Run at Baird Park on January 20th from 7:30am to 12:00pm to raise money for S.A.D.D. (Students Against Destructive Decisions). 100% of the proceeds will go toward raising funds to bring the Herren Project back to Arlington. Sign up at https://arlingtonschools.revtrak.net/sadd/#/v/3k-entry-fee or on the day of the event.

Dr. Lyons sent this message this morning. Some parents are calling to say that they could not hear the message. We are looking into this issue with SchoolMessenger.

"Late last evening the State Police received a report of a non-specific threat on social media involving Arlington High School students. They, along with the Dutchess County Sheriffs' Office investigated this matter throughout the night and by 5:00am this morning had determined that the potential threat was not credible. We thank the individual who reported this information and law enforcement for their diligence in following up on this matter. This is an appropriate time to remind you of the availability of our anonymous Quick Tip feature on the District web page at www.arlingtonschools.org. If you have any questions or concerns, please do not hesitate to reach out to the high school at 486-4480 or the Central Administrative Offices at 486-4460."
